& Gold Cup]] | Regional cup apps = 12 | Regional cup first = [[1963 CONCACAF Championship|1963]] | Regional cup best = Runners-Up, [[1963 CONCACAF Championship|1963]], [[1981 CONCACAF Championship|1981]] | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport | [[CONCACAF Championship]]}} {{MedalSilver | '''[[1963 CONCACAF Championship|1963 El Salvador]]''' | NA}} {{MedalBronze | '''[[1977 CONCACAF Championship|1977 Mexico]]''' | NA}} {{MedalBronze | '''[[1981 CONCACAF Championship|1981 Honduras]]''' | NA}} {{MedalSport | [[UNCAF Nations Cup]]}} {{MedalBronze | '''[[1995 UNCAF Nations Cup|1995 El Salvador]]''' | NA}} {{MedalBronze | '''[[1997 UNCAF Nations Cup|1997 Guatemala]]''' | NA}} {{MedalBronze | '''[[2001 UNCAF Nations Cup|2001 Honduras]]''' | NA}} {{MedalBronze | '''[[2003 UNCAF Nations Cup|2003 Panama]]''' | NA}} {{MedalSport | [[Central American and Caribbean Games]]}} {{MedalBronze | '''[[1935 Central American and Caribbean Games|1935 San Salvador]]''' | NA}} {{MedalGold | '''[[1954 Central American and Caribbean Games|1954 Mexico City]]''' | NA}} {{MedalGold | '''[[2002 Central American and Caribbean Games|2002 San Salvador]]''' | NA}} {{MedalSport | [[CCCF Championship]]}} {{MedalSilver | '''[[1941 CCCF Championship|1941 San JosÃ©]]''' | NA}} {{MedalGold | '''[[1943 CCCF Championship|1943 San Salvador]]''' | NA}} {{MedalSilver | '''[[1961 CCCF Championship|1961 San JosÃ©]]''' | NA}} }} '''El Salvador's national football team''' (''SelecciÃ³n de fÃºtbol de El Salvador'' in Spanish) represents [[El Salvador]] in international [[association football|football]] and is sanctioned by the [[FederaciÃ³n SalvadoreÃ±a de FÃºtbol]] (FESFUT). In 1899, [[Santa Ana, El Salvador|Santa Ana]] and [[San Salvador, El Salvador|San Salvador]] met for the first hosted football game in El Salvador. El Salvador's national football team's first match was in September 1921, when they were invited to participate in [[Independence Centenary Games|a tournament]] to celebrate 100 years of [[Central American declarations of independence|Central American Independence]]. El Salvador has made two [[FIFA World Cup]] appearances: first in [[1970 FIFA World Cup|1970]] and again in [[1982 FIFA World Cup|1982]], but have never progressed beyond the first group stage of a finals tournament. They were the [[1943 CCCF Championship|1943 CCCF]] champions, and finished in second-place in the [[1941 CCCF Championship|1941]] and [[1961 CCCF Championship|1961]] championships. They have competed in the [[CONCACAF Championship|CONCACAF regional tournaments]] thirteen times, finishing as runners-up in [[1963 CONCACAF Championship|1963]] and [[1981 CONCACAF Championship|1981]]. ''La Selecta'' also competes in the biennial [[Central American Cup|UNCAF Nations Cup]], the [[Football at the Pan American Games|Pan American Games]], the [[Football at the Summer Olympics|Olympics]], and have achieved two gold medals in the [[Central American and Caribbean Games]]. The [[Estadio CuscatlÃ¡n]], also known as ''"El Coloso de Montserrat"'' and ''"La Catedral del Espectaculo"'', is the official home stadium of the El Salvador national football team. Since 2008, the national team has had a [[Kit (association football)|kit]] sponsorship contract with England based supplier [[Mitre Sports International|Mitre]]. {{As of|2011|9}}, [[RaÃºl DÃ­az Arce]] is the top-scorer with 39 goals, while [[Leonel CÃ¡rcamo]] has the record of being the most capped Salvadoran player with 84 appearances. The El Salvador national football team has presented itself with 41 managers in total, in the national team, and currently the head coach is [[RubÃ©n Israel]]. ==History== ===Beginnings of the national team=== [[Salvadoran Football Association|Salvadoran football]] had its birth in the city of [[Santa Ana, El Salvador|Santa Ana]] on a field called Campo Marte. This was the first time a [[Association football|football]] game was hosted in El Salvador. That first game took place on July 26, 1899 among players from [[Santa Ana, El Salvador|Santa Ana]] and [[San Salvador]]. Both teams had several foreign players from England who are credited with introducing football to El Salvador. The local team won the game 2â0.{{cite web |url=http://www.elbaloncuscatleco.com/historia.html |title=Historia |author=Gomez, Omar |date= |work= |publisher=El Balon Cusctatleco |accessdate=16 May 2011 |language=Spanish |trans_title=History}} Although El Salvador played a few games in the early part of the 20th century, they did not become a fully committed national team until 1921 when players such as JosÃ© Pablo Huezo, Carlos Escobar Leiva or Santiago Barrachina revolutionized football in the country.{{cite web|last=Hatcher |first=Dan|title=El Salvador Soccer Team Name Ideas|url=http://danhatcher.com/blog/tag/soccer-team-name-ideas/|accessdate=2010-11-01|date=2008-09-14}} In September 1921, El Salvador were invited to [[Guatemala]] to take part in the [[Independence Centenary Games]], to celebrate 100 years of [[Central American declarations of independence|Central American Independence]].{{cite web |url=http://www.elsalvador.com/especiales/2008/selecta2008/historia.asp |title=Nace la pasion... |author= |date= |work= |publisher=elsalvador.com |accessdate=16 May 2011 |language=Spanish |trans_title=The passion is born... }}{{cite web |url=http://fesfut.org.sv/historia.php |title=Historia del FÃºtbol SalvadoreÃ±o |author= |date= |work= |publisher=fesfut.org.sv |accessdate=16 May 2011 |language=Spanish |trans_title=History of Salvadoran Football}} The tournament was compromised as only [[Guatemala national football team|Guatemala]], [[Honduras national football team|Honduras]], [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]], and El Salvador were able to participate. By fact, Guatemalans and Costa Ricans had more experience with football than the Salvadorans and Hondurans.{{cite web|url=http://www.elsalvador.com/noticias/EDH_DEPORTES/figurauydeportes/Portada.pdf|title=el nacimiento de 'la selecta'|publisher=El Diario de Hoy|accessdate=28 August 2011|language=Spanish|format=PDF}} It was a [[single-elimination tournament]], or round-robin format, with Guatemala playing Honduras and El Salvador playing Costa Rica. El Salvador, which were dressed with white shorts and black shirt, underwent the classic [[2â3â5]] scheme with Carlos Escobar Leyva; Spanish resident Santiago Barrachina, JosÃ© Pablo Huezo; BenjamÃ­n Sandoval, Emilio Dawson, and Frenchman Emilio Detruit; VÃ­ctor Recinos, brothers Guillermo, and JosÃ© E. Alcaine, Guillermo Sandoval and Enrique Lindo. By the first half Costa Rica had scored 3 goals, and by the final whistle of 80 minutes (40 minutes for each half) won 7â0.{{cite web | url= http://www.rsssf.com/tablese/elsal-intres.html |title= 1921 to 2008 El Salvador match results by "Barrie Courtney" |publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=}} Despite the loss, this tournament is seen by many as the starting point of the El Salvador national team. After the 1921 Guatemala tournament, El Salvador only played three other international friendlies against Costa Rica and Honduras. El Salvador lost the first match 3â0 against Costa Rica, while the second and third ended in a 1â0 loss and 0â0 draw against Honduras. On 7 December 1928, El Salvador recorded its first ever win: a 5â0 victory over Honduras, the team that would later become their traditional rivals. The game was played at Campo Marte [[San Salvador, El Salvador|San Salvador]] and was not only El Salvador's first ever recorded win, but also the first time the team had scored in an international match. On the day, Gustavo "Taviche" Marroquin become the first ever Salvadoran player to score five goals in a single game for the El Salvador national football team, a feat later equaled by [[Miguel Cruz]] and [[Rudis Corrales]]. === 1930s === In the early 1930s, El Salvador appointed its first official national coach, American national [[Mark Scott Thompson]], in preparation for the [[1930 Central American and Caribbean Games]] in [[Havana, Cuba]].{{cite web |url=http://www.elbaloncuscatleco.com/directores.html |title=Los Directores en La Selecta |author=Gomez, Omar |date= |work= |publisher=El Balon Cuscatleco |accessdate=16 May 2011 |language=Spanish |trans_title=The Directors of ''La Selecta''}} El Salvador finished in fourth place at the games.{{cite web |url=http://www.elbaloncuscatleco.com/jdcac.html |title=El Salvador en Los Juegos Deportivos |author=Gomez, Omar |date= |work= |publisher=El Balon Cuscatleco |accessdate=16 May 2011 |language=Spanish |trans_title=El Salvador in Sportive Games}} The [[FederaciÃ³n SalvadoreÃ±a de FÃºtbol]], the official governing [[Association football|football]] organization in El Salvador, was founded in 1935. By this time, El Salvador were coached by Spaniard [[Pablo Ferre ElÃ­as]]. The El Salvador-hosted [[1935 Central American and Caribbean Games]] took place in the new government funded [[Estadio Jorge "MÃ¡gico" GonzÃ¡lez|Estadio Flor Blanca]], at that time the biggest stadium in the country. The Salvadoran squad consisted of Edmundo Majano as goalkeeper; Tobias Rivera and Raul Castro in defense; AmÃ©rico Gonzalez and Napolean CaÃ±as as midfielders; and Alex Morales, Rogelio Aviles, Fidel Quintanilla, Miguel âAmericanoâ Cruz, and Andres Hernandez as strikers. Previously the national team had worn black and white striped jerseys and this was the first time they turned out in a new blue strip. The team improved their performance over the previous competition to finish in third place as bronze medal winners.{{cite web |author=Garin, Erik |coauthors=Morrison, Neil |title= Central American Games 1935 (El Salvador) | url= http://www.rsssf.com/tablesc/cag35.html| publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=14 May 2011 | date=21 Apr 2011}} By 1938 the [[FederaciÃ³n SalvadoreÃ±a de FÃºtbol]] had become affiliates of [[FIFA]].{{cite web | title= El Salvador| url= http://www.fifa.com/associations/association=slv/index.html | publisher=[[FIFA]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=}} Once again the El Salvador national football team participated in the [[1938 Central American and Caribbean Games]] in [[Panama]], which was won by {{nft|Mexico}} with Costa Rica in second place. El Salvador won two games and lost three out of its the five played. A match for third place between Colombia and El Salvador was scheduled but was cancelled due to bad physical state of the players. El Salvador finished in fourth place by goal difference.{{cite web |author=Frank Ballesteros, Myk Cameron, Barrie Courtney, Erik Garin, and Neil Morrison |title= Central American and Caribbean Games Games 1938 (Panama) | url= http://www.rsssf.com/tablesc/cag38.html| publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=14 May 2011 | date=24 Feb 2004}} === 1940sâ1950s === On April 26, 1940, the first national football federation was approved, with Dr. Luis Rivas Palacios as president. In 1941, the first international competition in the [[CONCACAF]], the continental governing body for football in North America, Central America and the Caribbean, the [[CCCF Championship|Central American and Caribbean Championship (CCCF)]] took place in Costa Rica. El Salvador took part for the first time alongside teams from Costa Rica, {{nft|CuraÃ§ao}}, Panama, and {{nft|Nicaragua}}. El Salvador were runners-up, recording two wins, one tie, and one loss. The [[1943 CCCF Championship]] took place in San Salvador with the participation of Guatemala, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica. The El Savador team were coached by former national player [[AmÃ©rico GonzÃ¡lez]]. At the end of the tournament, El Salvador and Guatemala ended up with the same number of points and so had to play a tiebreaker. On December 21, Guatemala failed to show up for the match resulting in El Salvador declaring themselves 1943 CCCF Championship winners by goal difference. This was the country's first international title. El Salvador's 10â1 win over Nicaragua set the team's record for the most goals scored in a single game. It was also the second time a Salvadoran player (Miguel "Americano" Cruz) had scored five goals in a single match. El Salvador participated in the [[1946 CCCF Championship]], hosted in [[Costa Rica]], alongside six other participants. The national team finished in second place, winning three matches and losing two. In 1948, the El Salvador national football team participated in its fourth CCCF Championship, the [[1948 CCCF Championship]] in [[Guatemala]] alongside teams from five other countries. For the third time, Costa Rica won the championship with El Salvador finishing in fifth place. El Salvador were invited by Brazil but turned down an invitation to play in the [[1950 FIFA World Cup]], and did not participate in the playoffs for the subsequent World Cups in [[1954 FIFA World Cup|1954]], [[1958 FIFA World Cup|1958]], [[1962 FIFA World Cup|1962]], and [[1966 FIFA World Cup|1966]]. Reasons for these refusals to participate might have possibly be due to economic issues since in those times they had never played so far from home. At that time it had a good quad with players like goalkeeper Manuel "tamalon" Garay, Rafael "chapuda" Reyes, Conrado Miranda, Miguel "americano" Cruz, Rafael Corado and Mando Rivas, to name a few. At the group stage of the [[1950 Central American and Caribbean Games]] in Mexico, El Salvador recorded two wins, one tie, and one loss. They began the final round by beating CuraÃ§ao 3â1, but lost their other two matches leaving them in fifth place. In 1953, the El Salvador national football team took part in its fifth CCCF Championship, the [[1953 CCCF Championship]] held in [[Costa Rica]]. together with seven other national teams. Costa Rica became champions for the fourth time, and El Salvador finished in fifth place. El Salvador won their second international title in 1954 under the direction of [[Carbilio Tomasino]], and a team consisting of Yohalmo Aurora, Manuel "tamalones" Garay, Hugo Moreno, Armando Larin, Luis Regalado, Conrado Miranda, Fernando Barrios, Ramon "pezote" Chavez, Jose Hernandez, Mario Montoya, Juan Francisco "cariota" Barraza, Ricardo "chilenito" Valencia, Alfredo "Baiza" Ruano, and Obdulio "calulo" Hernandez. They debuted against {{nft|Colombia}} in a 2â2 tie, beat {{nft|Cuba}} 3â1, beat Mexico 3â2 and finally beat Panama 1â0 with a goal by "Cariota" Barraza. The 3â2 victory against Mexico, with two goals from Mario Montoya (16',36') and one from Ricardo Valencia (37'), was the first victory by a Central American team against Mexico. At the 1955 CCCF Championship in Honduras, El Salvador's sixth, the national team took part along with seven other participants. For the fifth time Costa Rica crowned themselves champions with El Salvador as 4th place. === 1960s === The El Salvador football team participated in its seventh CCCF Championship, the [[1961 CCCF Championship]] in Costa Rica, in competition with nine other teams with El Salvador finishing in fourth place. El Salvador hosted the first [[1963 CONCACAF Championship qualification|CONCACAF Championship qualification]] tournament (a replacement for the CCCF Championship) in 1963. There were nine other participants, with Costa Rica becoming the first CONCACAF champions, and El Salvador finishing as runners-up. Chilean [[HernÃ¡n Carrasco Vivanco]] became coach in 1964 and would later revolutionize Salvadoran football. He led the national team for the first time at the [[1965 CONCACAF Championship]] in Guatemala, where they won 2â1 against Costa Rica and 3â1 against {{nft|Haiti}}. The team tied 1 game, losing two eventually finishing in fourth place. In 1966 the El Salvador football team took part in the Central American and Caribbean Games for the sixth time in a [[1966 Central American and Caribbean Games|competition]] that took place in [[Puerto Rico]]. The national team participated alongside seven other teams, finishing in fourth place. The first elimination rounds at the CONCACAF level were in preparation for the [[Football at the 1960 Summer Olympics|1960 Summer Olympics]] in Rome, Italy, whilst similar elimination rounds were held for Central American members prior to the [[Football at the 1964 Summer Olympics|Tokyo 1964 Summer Olympics]]. In 1968 El Salvador qualified for the [[1968 Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]] for the first time.{{cite web | author=Gomez, Omar | title=El Salvador en Juegos Olimpicos {{es icon}} | url= http://www.elbaloncuscatleco.com/olimpicos.html | publisher=Elbaloncuscatleco.com | accessdate=2011-08-21 | date=}} They lost 4â0 to {{nft|Hungary}},{{cite web|publisher=FIFA|title=Olympic Football Tournament Mexico City 1968 Hungary-El Salvador|url=http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=512/edition=197099/matches/match=32096/report.html|accessdate=2011-02-08|date=}} 3â1 to {{nft|Israel}},{{cite web|publisher=FIFA|title=Olympic Football Tournament Mexico City 1968 Israel-El Salvador|url=http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=512/edition=197099/matches/match=32103/report.html|accessdate=2011-02-08|date=}} and tied 1â1 with {{nft|Ghana}}.{{cite web|publisher=FIFA|title=Olympic Football Tournament Mexico City 1968 Ghana-El Salvador|url=http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=512/edition=197099/matches/match=32111/report.html|accessdate=2011-02-08|date=}} The coach by this time was [[Rigoberto Guzman]]. Gregorio Bundio and his assistant Jose Santacolomba coached the team in the qualifying stages for the [[1970 FIFA World Cup]]. This would be the first time that El Salvador would participate in this qualifying tournament. For this World Cup, CONCACAF would be represented by Mexico (host of the World Cup) and another national team. El Salvador won group 3, playing four games, winning three and losing one. Their record was 10 goals for and 5 goals against with 6 points. As a result they qualified for a 3-game playoff against the group 2 winner, Honduras. Immediately following the match an eighteen-year old Salvadoran girl Amelia BolaÃ±os shot herself in the heart, and was subsequently regarded as a martyr in El Salvador, with her funeral being televised and the El Salvador president and national football team walking behind her coffin.{{cite web|title=A game of life and death|url=http://www.thenational.ae/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090606/SPORT/706059844/1100|publisher=The National.ae|accessdate=22 August 2010|author=Simon Kuper|date=5 June 2009}}{{cite web|title=Football's just a game ... isn't it?|url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2010-05-12-footballs-just-a-game-isnt-it|publisher=Mail & Guardian online|accessdate=22 August 2010|author=Richard Ingham|date=12 May 2010}} The second game, on 15 June 1969 in the Salvadoran capital of [[San Salvador]], which was won 3â0 by El Salvador, was followed by even greater violence.{{cite book |title=Wars and Peace Treaties, 1816â1991 |last=Goldstein |first=Erik |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1992 |publisher=Routledge |location= |isbn=9780203976821 |pages=195â6 |url=http://books.google.ie/books?id=VjWnMm53xQ8C&pg=PA195&dq=football+war+honduras+el+salvador# |accessdate=4 July 2010 }} A play-off match took place in [[Mexico City]] on 26 June 1969. El Salvador won 3â2 after [[extra time]]. As a result of existing tensions being exacerbated by the football matches, on 14 July 1969 the two countries began the a 100 hour long war known as the [[Football War]]. As a result of the conflict, El Salvador and Honduras were disqualified from entering the [[1969 CONCACAF Championship qualification]]. The final set of qualifying games for the 1970 FIFA World Cup took place against Haiti. The first leg was won by El Salvador in Haiti, 2â1, with goals from Elver Acevedo (43') and Mauricio 'Pipo' Rodriguez (62'). The second lef was lost 3â0. The third game on 8 October 1969 was won by El Salvador with a goal by Juan Ramon "Mon" Martinez (14' a.e.t.). The El Salvador national football team qualified for their first FIFA World Cup, even though it was their first time in the qualifying stages. === 1970s === In their first ever World Cup Finals appearance, at the 1970 FIFA World Cup, El Salvador lost their first game 3â0 to [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] in Mexico City on June 3.{{cite web |title=FIFA Match Report for Belgium-El Salvador on June 3, 1970 |url=http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=32/results/matches/match=1747/report.html |publisher=[[FIFA]] |accessdate=2010-11-14 | date=2006-04-12}} The second match was played against the [[Mexico national football team|host nation]], Mexico, on 7 June. The game turned on a controversial moment near the end of the first half with the score at 0â0. Egyptian referee Hussain Kandil awarded a free kick to El Salvador in their own half. However a Mexican player took the free-kick, passing to another Mexican player who scored. The Salvadoran players protested vigorously, to the extent of physically jostling Bermudan linesman Keith Dunstan, but the goal was allowed to stand. El Salvador restarted the game by kicking the ball into the crowd in protest. They eventually lost the game 4â0.{{cite web | title= FIFA Match Report for Mexico-El Salvador on June 7, 1970| url= http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=32/results/matches/match=1820/report.html| publisher=[[FIFA]] | accessdate=2010-11-11 | date=2007-09-20}} The team's third and final game occurred on June 10 with El Salvador losing the game 2â0 to the [[USSR national football team|USSR]] in Mexico City, to finish at the bottom of Group A.{{cite web | title=FIFA Match Report for Soviet Union-El Salvador on June 10, 1970 | url= http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=32/results/matches/match=1823/report.html | publisher=[[FIFA]] | accessdate=2010-11-11 | date=2006-04-12}} "El Pajaro Picon Picon" was a Colombian song written by Eliseo Herrera which was very popular in El Salvador during the qualifying stages of the 1970 World Cup. During a radio show, Mauricio Bohorquez parodied the song, which he named "Arriba con la Seleccion". That parody became so famous that it became the "official anthem" of the El Salvador national football team.{{cite web |url=http://lacomunidad.elpais.com/deralte/2011/1/17/el-pajaro-picon-picon-y-guerra-del-futbol |title=El PÃ¡jaro PicÃ³n y La Guerra de FÃºtbol {{es icon}} |publisher=lacomunidad.elpais.com |accessdate=17 January 2011 }} At the [[1971 CONCACAF Championship]], which was hosted on [[Trinidad and Tobago|Trinidadian]] soil, El Salvador advanced from the first round with an aggregate score of 4â2 against {{nft|Nicaragua}}. In the second round, El Salvador withdrew from the playoff when they had to play against Honduras with Honduras eventually making the finals. The national team took part in the [[1973 CONCACAF Championship qualification]] process for the [[1974 FIFA World Cup]] but they did not advance to the [[1973 CONCACAF Championship|final stage]] after they were eliminated by {{nft|Guatemala}} with an aggregate score of 0â2 (0â1, 0â1).{{cite web | title=El Salvador en eliminatorias rumbo a La Copa Mundo {{es icon}} | url= http://www.elbaloncuscatleco.com/cm.html | publisher=Elbaloncuscatleco.com | accessdate=2011-04-21 | date=}} The team was managed by [[Hector D'Angelo]]. In 1975 El Salvador participated at the [[Pan American Games]] for the first time at the [[Football at the 1975 Pan American Games|VII (7) Pan American Games]], hosted in [[Mexico]]. The national team participated in a group that included {{nft|Brazil}}, Nicaragua, and {{nft|Costa Rica}}. They debuted with a 4â1 score against Nicaragua on October 14 with 3 goals from [[Norberto Huezo|"Pajarito" Huezo]] and the debut of Francisco "Paco" Jovel. Then they played against Brazil on the 15thâfor the first time in historyâand lost 0â2. They ended the tournament by playing against Costa Rica, where they tied 0â0, and wherein [[Luis RamÃ­rez Zapata|"Pele" Zapata]] missed a penalty. They could not proceed to the next stage, and finished at third place in Group D.{{cite web|publisher=[[RSSSF]]|author=Garin, Erik|title=Panamerican Games 1975 (Mexico)|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesp/panam75.html|date=2008-11-27}} At the [[1977 CONCACAF Championship qualification]], ''La Azul'' played against four other teams on a home-and-away basis. The group winner (Guatemala) and runner-up (El Salvador) advanced to the [[1977 CONCACAF Championship|Final Round]]. In the final round, El Salvador played five games; they won two, drew one, and lost two with 5 points. They finished in thirs place, below Haiti (7 points) and Mexico (10 points). In 1978 the El Salvador football team took part in the Central American and Caribbean Games for the seventh time in the [[1978 Central American and Caribbean Games|competition]] that took place in [[Colombia]]. For the fourth time, Cuba was crowned champions. El Salvador finished in ninth place. === 1980s === At the [[1981 CONCACAF Championship qualification]], ''La Azul'' and five other teams played against each other on a home-and-away basis. The group winner (Honduras) and runner-up (El Salvador) advanced to the final round. On November 19, 1981, in the [[1981 CONCACAF Championship|hexagonal]] at [[Honduras]], El Salvador beat {{nft|Haiti}} by 1â0 with a penalty kick taken by [[Norberto Huezo]]. {{nft|Honduras}} tied with {{nft|Mexico}}, meaning the national team scored more points than Mexico and qualified for the second time for a [[1982 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]], alongside Honduras. In the hexagonal games, ''La Selecta'' won 1â0 over Mexicoâwith a memorable goal from [[Ever Hernandez]] on November 6âand Haiti. The national team tied 0â0 against Cuba and Honduras and lost to Canada 0â1. The national team was under the direction of [[Mauricio Alonso RodrÃ­guez|Mauricio "Pipo" RodrÃ­guez]].{{cite web | title=La historia de la clasificacion a la Copa Mundo 1982 {{es icon}} | url= http://www.elbaloncuscatleco.com/cm82.html | publisher=Elbaloncuscatleco.com | accessdate=2011-04-21 | date=}} In 1982 El Salvador took a 20-man squad (two players short of the normal 22, for controversial and economical problems), coached by Mauricio "Pipo" RodrÃ­guez, to Spain. The team's experience was an unhappy one. In their first match on June 15 in [[Elche]], they were defeated 10â1 by [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]], a scoreline that stands as a [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] record to this day.{{cite web | title=Did You Know? table| url=http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=32/results/matches/match=1823/report.html | publisher=[[FIFA]] | accessdate=2006-04-12 | date=2010-11-11}} One comfort was that [[Luis RamÃ­rez Zapata|Luis Baltazar RamÃ­rez Zapata]] scored the country's first World Cup goal during the game, albeit at a point when the Salvadorans were already down 5â0.{{cite web | title= FIFA Match Report for Hungary-El Salvador on June 15, 1982| url= http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=59/results/matches/match=896/report.html | publisher=[[FIFA]] | accessdate=2010-11-11 | date=2006-04-12}} El Salvador managed to regain some pride in their subsequent games: displaying much-improved levels of organisation and commitment, they lost 1â0 to [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] on June 19 in Elche and 2â0 to the then-reigning world champions, [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]], in [[Alicante]] on June 23.{{cite web | title= FIFA Match Report for Belgium-El Salvador on June 19, 1982| url= http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=59/results/matches/match=774/report.html | publisher=[[FIFA]] | accessdate=2010-11-12 | date= 2006-04-12}}{{cite web | title= FIFA Match Report for Argentina-El Salvador on June 23, 1982 | url= http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=59/results/matches/match=751/report.html | publisher=[[FIFA]] | accessdate=2010-11-11 | date=2006-04-12}} El Salvador, within many surprises among the Spanish press for the qualification to the 1982 FIFA World Cup, had a terrible experience in personal terms. First of all, El Salvador took 20 players to the World Cup, leaving behind [[Gilberto Quinteros]] and Miguel GonzÃ¡lez. According to [[Luis Guevara Mora]], goalkeeper of the team by that time, the Salvadoran Football Association decided to take a few friends of the association in exchange for such players that had participated in the qualification process. By the way, those ''friends'' never took part with the team in the notorious World Cup but did take a trip around Europe. Some fellow players tried to gather in some money to help pay for the flight. El Salvador took 3 days to arrive to Spain and was the last team to do so. [[Adidas]] sent four white and three blue uniforms for each player. But mysteriously only three white and one blue remained. The remaining uniforms were taken away by the association. They decided to play with the white uniform and keep the blue as a keepsake. Someone had stolen the balls that the team would train with. The day prior to the match against Hungary, the Hungarians had the 25 balls the organization had given them and trained with them. El Salvador had never seen Hungary play. The only knowledge that they had about the team was a lone video that they had bought. When Zapata scored against Hungary, some Salvadorans cried out to Zapata not to celebrate the goal effusively because it might make the Hungarians mad. The fourth goal of Hungary was the fault of the deafness of [[JosÃ© Francisco Jovel|Francisco Jovel]]. Jovel had received a heavy blow on the cheek and almost could not hear. So when Guevara Mora cried off to stop a ball, the defender did not hear him. The rejection was defective, Mora had left the goal and the Hungarian player only had to push it inside. After the match against Hungary, the Salvadoran squad had a tense meeting with the coaching staff. The continuing matches against Belgium and Argentina were managed by players Jovel, Huezo and Fagoaga.{{cite web|last=Gomez|first=Omar|title=El Salvador en la Copa Mundo 1982|url=http://www.elbaloncuscatleco.com/cm82-mundial.html|publisher=elbaloncuscatleco.com|accessdate=2011-08-24|language=Spanish}} Even though they had a bad experience in the World Cup, El Salvador had some relieved moments. Jorge "Magico: Gonzalez was considered by the national and international press as the best player. "Magico" Gonzalez stayed in Spain were he played for [[CÃ¡diz CF]], [[Real Valladolid]] and [[F.C. Barcelona|Barcelona]]. Ricardo Guevara Mora, the goalkeeper, was the youngest player to play at the 1982 FIFA World Cup with 20 years of age. In the [[1985 CONCACAF Championship qualification]], El Salvador and 15 other teams were paired up to play knockout matches on a home-and-away basis. With an aggregate score of 8â0 (5â0, 3â0) against {{nft|Puerto Rico}}, El Salvador passed to the first round of the [[1985 CONCACAF Championship|final tournament]]. They were unable to advance to the second round, with 5 points (2 won, 1 tied, 1 lost). In the [[1989 CONCACAF Championship qualification|qualifying stages]] they eliminated the {{nft|Netherlands Antilles}} 1â0 and 5â0, and in the [[1989 CONCACAF Championship|final round]] they placed fifth, with 2 points in 6 games (victories were then counted as two points). === 1990s === In the [[1991 UNCAF Nations Cup]], ''La Selecta'' defeated Nicaragua with an aggregate score of 5â2 (3â2, 2â0) at the first round. In the final round, they played three games, drawing in one and losing two. They ended in fourth place and thus did not advance to the [[1991 CONCACAF Gold Cup]].{{cite web | title=El Salvador en UNCAF {{es icon}} | url= http://www.elbaloncuscatleco.com/uncaf.html | publisher=Elbaloncuscatleco.com | accessdate=2011-04-21 | date=}}{{cite web | author=Mazet, FranÃ§ois |title=CONCACAF Championship, Gold Cup 1991 | url= http://www.rsssf.com/tables/91gc.html | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=9 July 2001}} In the [[1993 UNCAF Nations Cup]], ''La Selecta'' played three games, drawing in one and losing two. They ended in fourth place and thus did not advance to the [[1993 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. They were coached by [[Jorge Vieira]]. Also, in the qualifiers, they eliminated {{nft|Nicaragua}} (5â0,5â1), then finished first in a group composed of {{nft|Bermuda}} (0â1 and 4â1), {{nft|Canada}} (1â1 and 3â2), and {{nft|Jamaica}} (2â0, 2â1). Already in the [[1994 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONCACAF)|final quadrangular]], they debuted by beating {{nft|Mexico}} 2â1, but lost the next 4 games, losing all classification option. They came in third with 4 points in 6 games (victories were then counted as two points). In the first round of the [[1995 UNCAF Nations Cup]], they won their first two games. ''La Selecta'' won Belize 3â0 and Costa Rica 2â1. In the semifinals they lost against Guatemala 0â1, so they had to go for the third-place playoff against Costa Rica. In that game they won by a score of 2â1; goals came from [[RaÃºl DÃ­az Arce]] (18') and [[Jorge Humberto RodrÃ­guez|Jorge RodrÃ­guez]] (21'). For the first time they advanced to the [[CONCACAF Gold Cup|Gold Cup]]. At the [[1996 CONCACAF Gold Cup]], El Salvador defeated Trinidad and Tobago 3â2, with goals from [[RaÃºl DÃ­az Arce]] (34', 72' ([[penalty kick|pen.]]) and [[Ronald Cerritos]] (50'). They lost to the United States, and thus could not continue in the competition.{{cite web | title=El Salvador en CONCACAF {{es icon}} | url= http://www.elbaloncuscatleco.com/concacaf.html | publisher=Elbaloncuscatleco.com | accessdate=2011-04-21 | date=}}{{cite web | author=Stokkermans, Karel |title=CONCACAF Championship, Gold Cup 1996 | url= http://www.rsssf.com/tables/96gc.html | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=22 October 2001}} In the first round of the [[1997 UNCAF Nations Cup]], ''La Selecta'' lost to Honduras 3â0 but defeated Costa Rica 2â0. In the final round they lost against Guatemala 0â1, Costa Rica 0â1, and tied Honduras 0â0. They finished in third, with 1 point. They advanced to the [[1998 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. At the US-hosted [[1998 CONCACAF Gold Cup]], El Salvador were coached by [[Kiril Dojcinovski]]. In Group A, El Salvador tied with Guatemala 0â0 and lost to Brazil 0â4 and Jamaica 0â2.{{cite web | author=Stokkermans, Karel |title=CONCACAF Championship, Gold Cup 1998 | url= http://www.rsssf.com/tables/98gc.html | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=22 October 2001}} After the global stakes in [[1970 FIFA World Cup|1970]] and [[1982 FIFA World Cup|1982]], this was the [[1998 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONCACAF)|playoff]] which was closest to a return to a World Cup, which created great excitement among the fans in El Salvador. In the final round, the club finished in fifth place, with 10 points in as many games. In the first round of the [[1999 UNCAF Nations Cup]], El Salvador tied Guatemala 1â1 and defeated Nicaragua 1â0, with goals from [[Magdonio Corrales]]. In the final round they lost to Honduras 1â3, Guatemala 0â1, and Costa Rica 0â4. They finished in fourth place, with 0 points, and did not advance to the [[2000 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. They were coached by [[Marinho Peres|Mario Peres Ulibarri]].{{cite web|author=Courtney, Barrie |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesg/gold-cam99.html | title= Qualifying Tournament for Gold Cup 1999 | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=2 Mar 2005}} === 2000s === In the group stage of the Honduras-hosted [[2001 UNCAF Nations Cup]], El Salvador defeated Nicaragua by 3â0, defeated Panama 2â1, and tied with Honduras 1â1. At the final stage of that tournament, they tied Guatemala 0â0, Panama 1â1, and Costa Rica 1â1. El Salvador advanced to the [[2002 CONCACAF Gold Cup]] after ending up in third place. They were coached by [[Carlos Recinos]]. Still coached by Recinos, El Salvador lost to Mexico 0â1 in Group A of the 2002 Gold Cup. On January 23, they defeated Guatemala 1â0, with a goal from [[Santos Cabrera]] (58'). For the first time, they advanced to the Quarter-finals of a Gold Cup. On January 27, they lost to eventual champions United States by a score of 0â4.{{cite web | author=Gonzalez, Miguel Alvin |title=CONCACAF Championship, Gold Cup 2002 | url= http://www.rsssf.com/tables/02gc.html | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=29 April 2002}} The [[2002 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONCACAF)|2002 FIFA World Cup qualification process]] marked the beginning of the current decline in Salvadoran football, because after being a regular in the CONCACAF final round, the team was eliminated in the second round by Honduras and Jamaica, who later participated in the final round.{{cite web|author=Stokkermans, Karel |url=http://rsssf.com/tables/2002q.html#nca | title= World Cup 2002 Qualifying | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=26 November 2009}} In the [[2003 UNCAF Nations Cup]] in Panama, El Salvador managed to get third place, with [[Juan RamÃ³n Paredes]] as head coach. In the tournament El Salvador won against Panama 2â1, lost against Costa Rica 0â1, defeated Nicaragua 3â0, defeated Honduras 1â0, and lost against Guatemala.0â2. They qualified for the [[2003 CONCACAF Gold Cup]] alongside Guatemala and Costa Rica (Honduras went to the playoffs). El Salvador lost to the United States 0â2 in Group C of the 2003 Gold Cup. On July 16, they won over {{nft|Martinique}} 1â0 with a goal from defender [[Marvin Gonzalez]] (76'). For the second time, they had advanced to the Quarter-finals of a Gold Cup. On July 19, they lost to Costa Rica by 2â5. Three of the seven goals were penalty kicks counted by the referee, Mexican [[Felipe Ramos]].{{cite web | author= |title=CONCACAF Championship, Gold Cup 2003 | url= http://www.rsssf.com/tables/03gc.html | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=5 Mar 2005}} In the [[2005 UNCAF Nations Cup]] in Guatemala, El Salvador lost against Panama 0â1 and Costa Rica 1â2. They were not able to qualify for the [[2003 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. They were coached by [[Carlos Cavagnaro]].{{cite web|author=Courtney, Barrie |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesg/gold-cam05det.html | title= Qualifying Tournament for Gold Cup 2005 â Details | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=2 Mar 2005}} In the [[2006 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONCACAF)|2006 FIFA World Cup qualification process]], they eliminated Bermuda 2â1 and 2â2, but were defeated in the second round by the United States.{{cite web|author=Karel Stokkermans, Lars Aarhus, Jim Goloboy, Ian King, Jarek Owsianski, Malik Riaz Hai Naveed, JuliÃ¡n DÃ­az Rubio, MartÃ­n Tabeira, Antonio Zea and Andre Zlotkowski |url=http://rsssf.com/tables/2006q.html#nca | title= World Cup 2006 Qualifying | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=26 November 2009}} In the [[2007 UNCAF Nations Cup]], hosted on Salvadoran soil, El Salvador won over Belize and Nicaragua by 2â1, and tied with Guatemala with no goals. They advanced to the Semifinals as top of Group 1. At the semifinals, El Salvador lost to the eventual champions, Costa Rica, by two early goals. For the third place playoff, El Salvador lost 0â1 to Guatemala but still qualified to advance to the [[2007 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. The team was coached by [[Carlos de los Cobos]].{{cite web|author=Courtney, Barrie |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesg/gold-cam07det.html | title= Qualifying Tournament for Gold Cup 2007 â Details | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=2 May 2007}} At the 2007 CONCACAF Gold Cup, [[Ramon Sanchez]] (38') and [[Dennis Alas]] (81') scored to give the national team their only victory in the tournament against Trinidad and Tobago. They lost the following two matches against Guatemala 0â1 and United States 0â4.{{cite web | author= |title=CONCACAF Championship, Gold Cup 2007 | url= http://www.rsssf.com/tables/07gc.html | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=29 January 2009}} On June 16, 2007, a match that recognized the biggest defeat of the Salvadoran team was scheduled between El Salvador and Hungary. Many of the same players that had assisted the match between El Salvador and Hungary in the 1982 FIFA World Cup played again at the Estadio CuscatlÃ¡n. The stadium that filled 22,000 spectators saw a match tied at 2â2 with goals from [[LÃ¡zÃ¡r Szentes]] and [[Ferenc CsongrÃ¡di]] for Hungary and two goals from [[Luis RamÃ­rez Zapata]] for El Salvador. Victory was a foregone conclusion with the recognition of the past, to the best generation of El Salvador.{{cite web|last=Gomez|first=Omar|title=Los Mundialistas del '82 en el 2007|url=http://www.elbaloncuscatleco.com/cm82-2007.html|publisher=elbaoncuscatleco.com|accessdate=28 August 2011}} In the [[2009 UNCAF Nations Cup]], El Salvador defeated Belize 4â1, tied against Nicaragua 1â1 with an own-goal, and lost to Honduras 0â2. They qualified for the semifinals. At the semifinals, the game was called after 60 minutes of play when El Salvador was reduced to six players. Two El Salvador players, [[Alexander Escobar]] and [[Eliseo Quintanilla]], were awarded red cards in the first half, and [[Deris Umanzor]], [[Rodolfo Zelaya]], and goalkeeper [[Juan JosÃ© GÃ³mez]] were injured and had to leave the game after El Salvador had already exhausted their three substitutions. The game was awarded 3â0 to Costa Rica. In the third place playoff, Honduras earned a win over ''los Cuscatlecos'' with an only goal scored by [[Roger Espinoza]] (30').{{cite web|author=Lugo, Erik Francisco |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesg/gold-cam09.html | title= UNCAF Nations Cup 2009 | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=28 Oct 2010}} At the [[2009 CONCACAF Gold Cup]], El Salvador were in Group A, along with Costa Rica, Canada, and Jamaica. They debuted against Costa Rica, with two goals scored by [[Osael Romero]] in the 19th and 85th minute. The next two games were defeats by a score of 1â0. The team was still coached by [[Carlos de los Cobos]].{{cite web | author= |title=CONCACAF Championship, Gold Cup 2009 | url= http://www.rsssf.com/tables/09gc.html | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=25 March 2011}} === 2010s === For the [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONCACAF)|2010 FIFA World Cup qualification process]], the team passed the first round by defeating the weak selection of {{nft|Anguilla}} 12â0 and 4â0 and surprisingly, in the next round, eliminated Panama 0â1 and 3â1. By August 2008 they played the third phase against Costa Rica, {{nft|Haiti}} and {{nft|Suriname}}, after which they were in second place. El Salvador and five other teams that reached the fourth round formed one double-round-robin, home-and-away group. The top three teams qualified for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]]. The fourth place team qualified for a home-and-away play-off against the fifth-place team from CONMEBOL. After the qualifying round (final stage) the team was in fifth, with eight points. [[Rudis Corrales]] was top goalscorer of the qualification process with 8 in total.{{cite web|author=Ian King, Erik Francisco Lugo, Karel Stokkermans and Andre Zlotkowski |url=http://rsssf.com/tables/2010q.html#nca | title= World Cup 2010 Qualifying | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statisti cs Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=28 October 2010}} On 11 May 2010 The FIFA Emergency Committee suspended the Salvadoran Football Association (FESFUT) on account of government interference. This decision by FIFA was based on the fact that the statutes ratified by the FESFUT general assembly in August 2009 had not been formally entered in the country's official register, and that the government had failed to acknowledge the authority of the Normalisation Committee set up to represent FESFUT.{{cite web | title= Suspension of the Salvadoran Football Association | url= http://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/organisation/news/newsid=1209619/ | publisher=[[FIFA]] | accessdate=2010-11-12 | date=2010-04-12}} Consequently, FIFA considered that it was not possible for FESFUT to organise the elective general assembly in line with the action plan that had been drawn up, and suspended FESFUT. For the suspension to be lifted, Salvadoran authorities needed to recognize the legitimacy of the Normalisation Committee of the Salvadoran Football Association. The suspension was lifted on May 28. By FIFA lifting the suspension, El Salvador was allowed to participate in international tournaments at both club and national levels. El Salvador's under-21 team qualified for the CAC tournament in MayagÃ¼ez, Puerto Rico. However, CONCACAF made a decision to suspend football at the [[2010 Central American and Caribbean Games]] shortly thereafter. MetapÃ¡n and FAS participated in the CONCACAF Champions League. The Salvadoran referees selected for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] were able to participate in the World Cup. El Salvador will also be able to participate in the [[2012 Summer Olympics]].{{cite web | title= Suspension of Salvadoran Football Association lifted | url= http://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/organisation/news/newsid=1220034/ | publisher=[[FIFA]] | accessdate=2010-11-12 | date=2010-04-27}} At the [[2011 Copa Centroamericana]], formerly known as the UNCAF Nations Cup, El Salvador achieved fourth place. ''Los Cuscatlecos'' defeated Nicaragua 2â0 and Belize 5â2, and lost against Panama 2â0. At the semifinals they lost against Honduras once again by a 2â0 score. In the third place match, they lost to Panama in a penalty shootout by a score of 4â5. The team was coached by [[JosÃ© Luis Rugamas]], and qualified for the [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. Forward [[Rafael Burgos (footballer)|Rafael Burgos]] received the Golden Boot, with three goals.{{cite web|author=Lugo, Erik Francisco |coauthors=Torres, Steven |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesg/gold-cam2011.html | title= 2011 Copa Centroamericana | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=16 May 2011 | date=25 March 2011}} [[RubÃ©n Israel]], who took over El Salvador's coaching administration from JosÃ© Luis Rugamas in April 2011, introduced a new system and spirit into the team.{{cite web|url=http://www.elsalvadorfc.com/2011-04-06-israel-hemos-venido-a-honrar-el-trabajo | title= 'We have come to honor the work,' Israel {{es icon}}| publisher=elsalvadorfc.com | accessdate=2011-04-13}} At the [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup]], El Salvador started off holding Mexico to a 0â0 draw through 55 minutes, which included several close calls, but then allowed five goals in the next 35 to lose 5â0.{{cite web|author= McCauley, Kevin |url=http://www.sbnation.com/soccer/2011/6/5/2208429/mexico-vs-el-salvador-2011-gold-cup-final-score-copa-oro-chicharito-el-tri | title= Mexico Vs. El Salvador, 2011 Gold Cup: Final Score, El Tri Win 5-0; 'Chicharito' Javier Hernandez Nets Hat Trick | publisher=sbnation.com | accessdate=17 June 2011 | date=5 June 2011}} Against Costa Rica, [[Rodolfo Zelaya]] scored a 25 yard free kick opener before the half. It was until the fifth minute of injury time where it allowed an equalizing goal and settled for a 1â1 draw.{{cite web|author= McCauley, Kevin |url=http://www.sbnation.com/soccer/2011/6/9/2216543/costa-rica-vs-el-salvador-final-score-copa-oro-2011-gold-cup | title= Costa Rica Vs. El Salvador Final Score, Gold Cup 2011: Ticos Snatch Late Draw | publisher=sbnation.com | accessdate=17 June 2011 | date=9 June 2011}} El Salvador opened the doors to the quarterfinals as secondâbest third after they defeated Cuba 6â1. The goals were scored by 5 different players, including 2 from Rodolfo Zelaya. The goal difference was instrumental in El Salvador's qualification. A 1â1 draw with Panama and Canada enabled El Salvador to advance to their first quarterfinal berth since [[2003 CONCACAF Gold Cup|2003]] and third overall.{{cite web|author= Lewis, Michael |url=http://www.goldcup.org/page/GoldCup/NewsDetail/0,,12802~2378368,00.html | title= El Salvador ignoring past against Panama | publisher=goldcup.org | accessdate=17 June 2011 | date=17 June 2011}}{{cite web|author=Lugo, Erik Francisco |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tables/2011gc.html | title= 2011 CONCACAF Championship, Gold Cup 2011 | publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate=17 June 2011 | date=16 June 2011}} At the quarterfinals against Panama, Panamanian goalkeeper [[Jaime Penedo|Penedo]] stopped a penalty at the 23' from Salvadoran striker Rodolfo Zelaya, who also finished converting another penalty kick at 78' with a shot that was embedded in the upper left corner. Panama forced an extra time at 89', when striker [[Luis Tejada]] between several defenders drove a ball that bounced in front of goal and goalkeeper Miguel Montes managed to catch. The play left confused doubts whether the shot from Tejada was with his head or his hand. Eventually, the referee Walter Quesada decided that Montes caught the ball behind the goal line and ruled the goal to a 1â1 tie at the last minute. The coach of El Salvador called the decision an "error of haste"{{cite web|author=HernÃ¡ndez, Diego |url=http://www.goal.com/es-us/news/3443/el-salvador/2011/06/20/2540555/copa-oro-debemos-la-eliminaci%C3%B3n-a-un-error-humano-se%C3%B1al%C3%B3 | title= "Debemos la eliminaciÃ³n a un error humano", seÃ±alÃ³ Israel | publisher=goal.com | accessdate=19 June 2011 | date=19 June 2011 |language=Spanish |trans_title="We owe the elimination to a human error", says Israel}} that cost the whole team the pass to semifinals. Also, both teams played the extra time with 10 men after Panamanian striker [[Blas Perez]] and Captain [[Luis Anaya]] engaged in a discussion at the end of the second half. The Panamanians converted their 5 shots and Penedo stopped a shot by Salvadoran Dennis Alas to leave a Salvadoran loss of 3â5 after a 1â1 draw during the 90 minutes and 30 in overtime.{{cite web|author=CONCACAF |url=http://www.concacaf.com/page/GoldCup/NewsDetail/0,,12813~2378721,00.html | title= Panama returns to Gold Cup semifinals | publisher=CONCACAF.com | accessdate=19 June 2011 | date=19 June 2011}} For the [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONCACAF)|2014 FIFA World Cup qualification process]], El Salvador were second seed in the playoffs with a first round bye. ''La Selecta'' achieved its first victory and beat the {{nft|Dominican Republic}} by 3â2 but left many doubts in its debut. Despite a scoreless draw at the end of the first half, El Salvador regained its positionâthat being at homeâand won under goals by Rodolfo Zelaya (54', 77') and Christian Bautista (63').{{cite web|title=Triunfo bueno, marcador engaÃ±oso|url=http://www.elgrafico.com/gol-nacional/13-gol-nacional/17397-el-salvador-0-0-dominicana-primer-tiempo.html|publisher=elgrafico.com|accessdate=7 September 2011|language=Spanish}} El Salvador won 4â1 to the {{nft|Cayman Islands}}, a score that could have been bigger but the goalposts and the keeper prevented a higher defeat. El Salvador won their second game and took an important step in the qualifiers with goals from Christian Bautista (50') and defenders Luis Anaya (63', 80') and Xavier GarcÃ­a (90+3').{{cite web|last=Arteaga|first=Ernesto|title=Anaya, goleador inesperado|url=http://www.elgrafico.com/destacado-portada/36-destacadas/17557-anaya-goleador-inesperado.html|publisher=elgrafico.com|accessdate=7 September 2011|language=Spanish}} El Salvador visited the [[Estadio Panamericano, San CristÃ³bal]] in the Dominican Republic and came out with a victory of 2 to 1. Osael Romero scored the opening goal from the penalty spot and Lester Blanco would get the 2 to 1 with a powerful header. Even though, El Salvador received the necessary 3 points, the performance of the team was not as expected.{{cite web|title=Otra victoria con susto|url=http://www.elgrafico.com/gol-nacional/13-gol-nacional/18663-dominicana-0-0-el-salvador.html|work=elgrafico.com|accessdate=14 October 2011|language=Spanish}} El Salvador won 4-0 in the second playoff against the Cayman Islands in a game that was delayed over an hour and a half due to severe rain. Nevertheless, El Salvador showed a more attractive technique and earned the win. The goals were scored by VÃ­ctor Turcios (5'), Steve Purdy (12'), Jaime Alas (44') and Herbert Sosa (pen. 88'). The last being the 1000th goal scored in the history of the El Salvador national football team.{{cite web|title=El Salvador gana y llega a mil goles|url=http://www.elgrafico.com/gol-nacional/13-gol-nacional/18797-el-salvador-0-0-islas-caiman-primer-tiempo.html|work=elgrafico.com|accessdate=14 October 2011|language=Spanish}} ==FIFA World Cup record== {{main|El Salvador at the FIFA World Cup}} El Salvador have never advanced beyond the first round of the finals competition. El Salvador declined to participate at the 1950 FIFA World Cup. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !colspan=8|[[FIFA World Cup|FIFA World Cup record]] ! style="width:1%;" Salvador participated in the first CONCACAF Championship which included all countries of the region, North America, Central America and the Caribbean. During 1963 to 1971 only 5 championships were played. El Salvador achieving only a runner-up in 1963. From 1973 to 1989 no championship was played. The CONCACAF proclaimed champion of the region for the country that achieved the first place in qualifying to the FIFA World Cup. In 1990, CONCACAF again created a tournament as its showpiece event to crown the regional champion of the CONCACAF. The event was named the CONCACAF Gold Cup, with the USA hosting the first competition in 1991. In the 2002, 2003, and 2011 events El Salvador reached the Quarter-finals. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !Year !Round !{{Abbr|Pld|Played}} !{{Abbr|W|Won}} !{{Abbr|D*|Drawn}} ;CCCF Championship record The El Salvador national football team have competed in the CCCF Championship in seven occasions. El Salvador won the 1943 CCCF Championship, their only championship in the competition. El Salvador were runners-up in the editions of 1941 and 1961. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !Year !Round !{{Abbr|Pld|Played}} !{{Abbr|W|Won}} !{{Abbr|D*|Drawn}} !{{Abbr|L|Lost}} !{{Abbr|GF|Goals for}} !{{Abbr|GA|Goals against}} |- style="background:silver;" |{{Flagicon|CRC}} [[1941 CCCF Championship|1941]]||Second Place||4||2||1||1||15||8 |- style="background:gold;" |style="border: 3px solid red"|{{Flagicon|SLV}} [[1943 CCCF Championship|1943]]||'''Champions'''||6||4||1||1||28||11 |- style="background:LemonChiffon;" |{{Flagicon|CRC}} [[CCCF Championship|1946]]||Fourth Place||5||3||0||2||15||11 |- |{{Flagicon|GUA}} [[CCCF Championship|1948]]||Fifth Place||8||2||1||5||6||17 |- |{{Flagicon|PAN}} [[1951 CCCF Championship|1951]]||colspan=7|''Did not enter'' |- |{{Flagicon|CRC}} [[CCCF Championship|1953]]||Fifth Place||6||2||1||3||10||13 |- style="background:LemonChiffon;" |{{Flagicon|HON}} [[1955 CCCF Championship|1955]]||Fourth Place||6||3||0||3||8||13 |- |{{Flagicon|CUR}} [[CCCF Championship|1957]]||colspan=7|''Did not enter'' |- |{{Flagicon|CUB}} [[1960 CCCF Championship|1960]]||colspan=7|''Withdrew'' |- style="background:silver;" |{{Flagicon|CRC}} [[1961 CCCF Championship|1961]]||Second Place||6||4||1||1||18||7 |- |'''Total'''||7/10||41||20||5||16||100||80 |} :''*Denotes draws include knockout matches decided on [[penalty shootout (football)|penalty kicks]].'' :''**Red border color indicates tournament was held on home soil.'' Before the opening of the Estadio CuscatlÃ¡n the national stadium was the [[Estadio Jorge "MÃ¡gico" GonzÃ¡lez|Estadio Nacional de la Flor Blanca]] (now known as Estadio Jorge "''MÃ¡gico''" GonzÃ¡lez). During El Salvador's early run of existence, the team's national stadium was the Campo Marte, a 16 acre of land that housed a ministadium, (now known as ''Parque Infantil'') between 1928 and 1934.{{cite web | author=Guevara, Ricardo |title= El campo para los niÃ±os | url=http://www.elsalvador.com/noticias/EDICIONESANTERIORES/octubre11/VIDA/ | publisher=elsalvador.com | accessdate=22 May 2011 | date=11 October 1999 |language=Spanish |trans_title=The field for the children}} Succeeding, El Salvador played at the [[Estadio Jorge "MÃ¡gico" GonzÃ¡lez|Estadio Nacional de la Flor Blanca]] (now known as Estadio Jorge "''MÃ¡gico''" GonzÃ¡lez) in [[San Salvador]], El Salvador. It was first built in 19 April 1932 during the presidency of Maximiliano HernÃ¡ndez MartÃ­nez in preparation for the [[1935 Central American and Caribbean Games]]. On 24 March 1935 El Salvador played its first game at the Flor Blanca against Cuba and won 4â1.{{cite web | author=Gomez, Omar |title= Estadio Jorge Magico Gonzalez | url=http://www.elbaloncuscatleco.com/estadiomagico.html | publisher=El Balon Cuscatleco | accessdate=19 May 2011 | date= |language=Spanish |trans_title=Jorge "Magico" Gonzalez Stadium}} El Salvador played at this stadium for the [[1970 FIFA World Cup qualification#North, Central America and Caribbean (CONCACAF)|1970 FIFA World Cup qualification]], and accomplished to qualify for the 1970 FIFA World Cup. A one-off hame was played at the stadium to commemorate a major refurbishment, it was the last time El Salvador played a game in the stadium, on 15 November 2000, against Jamaica in the [[2002 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONCACAF)|2002 FIFA World Cup qualification]] process. In 1969, EDESSA (Estadios Deportivos de El Salvador Sociedad Anonima) first proposed the idea of a new national stadium.{{cite web | title= EDESSA primero ideas para la construcciÃ³n del Estadio CuscatlÃ¡n | url= http://www.1572-8.com/aa-company/deporte/estadiocuscatlan/estadio-historia.html | publisher=AA-Company | accessdate=19 may 2011 | date=7 June 2009 |language=Spanish |trans_title=EDESSA first thoughts for the construction of the Estadio CuscatlÃ¡n}} This came to fruition when the construction of the new national stadium, the Estadio CuscatlÃ¡n, began on March 24, 1971, with then-president of El Salvador, [[Fidel SÃ¡nchez HernÃ¡ndez|General Fidel SÃ¡nchez HernÃ¡ndez]], breaking ground. There were options for the name such of that of San Salvador, Fraternidad, and CuscatlÃ¡n but, of course, was named CuscatlÃ¡n. After 5 years of construction, the stadium was opened and held its very first game on July 24, 1976, in a friendly match. The game saw [[FuÃball-Bundesliga|German Bundesliga]] champions [[Borussia MÃ¶nchengladbach]] play the El Salvador national football team, with the match ending in a 2â0 victory to the German side. The German squad featured [[1974 FIFA World Cup]] champions, such as [[Berti Vogts]], [[Rainer Bonhof]], [[Jupp Heynckes]], [[Wolfgang Kleff]] and [[Jupp Heynckes]]. Also [[Allan Simonsen]], who eventually won the 1977 [[Ballon d'Or]] and later form part of [[FC Barcelona]]. El Salvador aligned itself with [[TomÃ¡s Pineda]] (Mauricio âTarzÃ¡nâ Alvarenga), Guillermo "Billy" RodrÃ­guez Bou, [[RamÃ³n Fagoaga]], [[Carlos Recinos|Humberto âImacasaâ Recinos]], Eduardo âConejoâ ValdÃ©s, VÃ­ctor âPatoâ Valencia, Warner SolÃ­s, [[FÃ©lix Pineda|FÃ©lix âGarrobitaâ Pineda]] (CÃ©sar âPiscuchaâ Acevedo), [[Luis RamÃ­rez Zapata|Luis "PelÃ©" RamÃ­rez Zapata]] ([[Luis Abraham Coreas|Abraham Coreas]]) & [[IsmaÃ©l DÃ­az|Ismael âCiscoâ DÃ­az]] ([[David Arnoldo Cabrera|David Cabrera]]). While Borussia played with [[Wolfgang Kneib]], [[Hans-JÃ¼rgen Wittkamp]], [[Berti Vogts]], [[Horst Wohlers]], [[Dietmar Danner]], [[Hans Klinkhammer]], [[Carsten Nielsen]], [[Uli Stielike]], [[Jupp Heynckes]] and [[Allan Simonsen]].{{cite news|last=Zelada|first=Victor|title=La primera pincelada azul|url=http://www.elsalvador.com/mwedh/epaper/20110725/EDH20110725DEP024P.PDF|accessdate=3 November 2011|newspaper=El Diario de Hoy (El Salvador)|date=25 July 2011}} Since that match, El Salvador has used the stadium for almost every major home game, and it is the official [[national stadium|home stadium]] of the El Salvador national football team and the Salvadoran club [[Alianza FC]].{{cite web | title= Monumental Estadio CuscatlÃ¡n| url= http://www.1572-8.com/aa-company/deporte/estadiocuscatlan/estadio-historia.html | publisher=elsalvadorguia.com | accessdate=2010-11-11 | date=2005-07-22}} On May 25, 1978, EDESSA agreed to sign a 99-year lease of the stadium to CLIMA (AsociaciÃ³n de Clubes de Liga Mayor A) to operate and control which events are held there. The Estadio CuscatlÃ¡n also features the following specifications: * A 45,925 capacity. * 15 entrances to the stadium. * 10 ticket offices available for ticket sales. * A irrigation system and French drain. * 4 fully equipped dressing rooms and a gymnasium. * A large 50 m2 [[LCD]] screen of high definition. * 6 robotic cameras strategically placed at the stadium for the transmission on the large screen. * Internal sound system with [[Dolby Digital#Dolby Digital Surround EX|Dolby Digital Surround]]. * 16 booths for radio and television transmission. * 3 electronic lighting towers, which have their north and south towers with 22 [[Mirror|beacons]] and in the center with 24 beacons and 10 [[halogen lamps]] each. * Parking for 8,500 cars. {{clear}} ==Recent results and upcoming fixtures== {{see also|El Salvador national football team season 2011}} {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%; font-size:90%;" |- ! Source: Soccerway{{cite web|title=EL SALVADOR|url=http://www.soccerway.com/teams/el-salvador/el-salvador/|publisher=Soccerway.com|accessdate=21 August 2011}} == Kit == {{Main|El Salvador national football team kit}} El Salvador's traditional first kit colour is blue with white trim, their second kit being white with blue trim. The current home and away kit features the traditional colours with the exception of bold curved trims that run from the center of the neck and open to the sides, forming two panels on the chest that contain the Mitre logo and emblem of the Salvadoran Football Federation. At the center of the kit the Salvadoran national emblem, once again, is shown. The right sleeve shows the national flag.{{cite web|title=El Salvador Mitre 2011/13 Home Jersey / Camiseta|url=http://footballfashion.org/wordpress/2011/08/03/el-salvador-mitre-201113-home-jersey-camiseta/|publisher=footballfasion.org|accessdate=4 August 2011}} {| |rightarm = 0000FF |shorts = 0000FF |socks = 0000FF |title = Training Kit }} | {{Football kit |pattern_la = |pattern_b = _els1113at |pattern_ra = |pattern_sh = _white stripes |pattern_so = _els10 |leftarm = FFFFFF |body = FFFFFF |rightarm = FFFFFF |shorts = FFFFFF |socks = 0000FF |title = Training Kit }} |} El Salvador and [[Mitre Sports International|Mitre]] announced a new partnership in 2008 that saw them supply the [[Central America]]n national football team with home and away kits, training, and bench wear until August 2010. Mitre, and their Panamanian partner, [[The Harari Group]], designed the kit that El Salvador used. The kit was showcased by the team on February 11, 2009 as they started their [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONCACAF)|FIFA World Cup qualifying]] campaign against [[Trinidad & Tobago national football team|Trinidad & Tobago]] in the [[CONCACAF]] (Central-American Football Union) Hexagonal Cup.{{cite web | title= Mitre (El Salvador)| url= http://www.mitre.com/el-salvador.html | publisher=[[Mitre Sports International|Mitre]] | accessdate=2010-11-11 | date=2009-03-09}} On October 22, 2010, the [[Salvadoran Football Association|FESFUT]] extended the contract with Mitre by four years.{{cite web | title= Mitre and El Salvador extend partnership | url= http://www.mitre.com/news/mitre-and-el-salvador-extend-partnership/ | publisher=[[Mitre Sports International|Mitre]] | accessdate=2010-11-22 | date=2010-11-02}} The first home and away kit made by Mitre feature a [[watermark]] of the country's national shield on the center of the shirt and some horizontal stripes along the kit. The current kit featured white remains along the neck, at the bottom of the kit, and over the shoulders. When this kit was introduced in 2009 it also introduced a new [[logo]] that replaced the typical logo of an "E" and an "S" surrounded by a circle.{{cite web|url=http://www.soccershopusa.com/Display_Product_Detail.asp?ProductID=3978&Cat1ID=10&Cat2ID=55&Cat3ID= | title= El Salvador Home Kit | publisher=Soccer Shop USA | accessdate=2010-11-14}} ==Players== ===Current squad=== The following 22-man squad was called-up for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification â CONCACAF Second Round#Group A|2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers]] against {{nft|Suriname}} on 11 and 15 November 2011.{{cite web|url=http://fesfut.org.sv/actualidad.php?id_noticia=552 | title=NOMINA SELECCION NACIONAL MAYOR DE EL SALVADOR QUE VIAJA A SURINAM {{es icon}}|accessdate=8 November 2011}} Caps and goals {{As of|2011|11|15|lc=y}}. "First of all thanks to the executive committee for welcoming me in this country and given me such a huge and so pretty responsibility, as is leading a national team", said the Uruguayan coach. The technical director explained that, "we have come here with our coaching staff to honor the work, beyond the mistakes and successes, the healthy intention is to work on Salvadoran football as a whole, working with major selections, but have a chronogram of action for youth teams, who are the future of the country."{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.elsalvadorfc.com/2011-04-06-israel-hemos-venido-a-honrar-el-trabajo |title= 'Hemos venido a horar el trabajo', Israel |publisher=elsalvadorfc.com |date=6 April 2011 |accessdate=17 April 2011 |language=Spanish |trans_title=We have come to honor the work,' Israel}} {{Fb cs header}} {{Fb cs staff |bg=y|p=Head coach |s={{Flagicon|Uruguay}} [[RubÃ©n Israel]]}} {{Fb cs staff |bg= |p=First assistant manager |s={{Flagicon|El Salvador}} [[JosÃ© Luis Rugamas]]}} {{Fb cs staff |bg= |p=Second assistant manager |s={{Flagicon|El Salvador}} [[MÃ¡gico GonzÃ¡lez|Jorge "MÃ¡gico" GonzÃ¡lez]]}} {{Fb cs staff |bg=y|p=First physical coordinator |s={{Flagicon|Uruguay}} NicolÃ¡s dos Santos}} {{Fb cs staff |bg=y|p=Second physical coordinator |s={{Flagicon|Argentina}} Esteban Coppia}} {{Fb cs staff |bg= |p=Goalkeeping coach |s={{Flagicon|El Salvador}} Carlos Felipe CaÃ±adas}} {{Fb cs staff |bg=y|p=Doctor |s={{Flagicon|El Salvador}} [[JosÃ© MarÃ­a Rivas]]}} {{Fb cs footer|u=8 November 2011 |s=[http://fesfut.org.sv/verfotos.php?id_album=31&nombre=Cuerpos_TÃ©cnicos FESFUT {{es icon}}]|date=April 2011}} ===Coaches=== Since the creation of the national team in 1921, several coaches have been in charge of managing El Salvador. From 1930 to 1935, [[Mark Scott Thompson]] was appointed as El Salvador's first ever manager. {{As of|2011|9}}, the El Salvador national football team has presented itself with 41 managers in the selection. It is reported that all 3 titles ([[1943 CCCF Championship|1943]],{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesc/cccf43.html|title=CCCF Championship 1943 (San Salvador, El Salvador, Dec 5â19)|date=2002-08-06|accessdate=2010-11-11|publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]]}} [[Football at the 1954 Central American and Caribbean Games|1954]]{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesc/cag54.html|title=Central American and Caribbean Games 1954 (Mexico)|date=2007-04-02|accessdate=2010-11-11|publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]]}} and [[Football at the 2002 Central American and Caribbean Games|2002]]{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesc/cag02.html|title=Central American and Caribbean Games 2002 (El Salvador)|date=2005-12-21|accessdate=2010-11-11|publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]]}}) have been won by Salvadoran born managers. [[Conrado Miranda]] has managed in 4 different occasions and [[Armando Contreras Palma|Armando Contreras]] in 3. [[Chilean people|Chilean]] [[HernÃ¡n Carrasco Vivanco|HernÃ¡n Vivanco]] was manager when El Salvador competed at their first [[1970 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://www.elbaloncuscatleco.com/directores.html|title=Directores |date=2008-01-24|accessdate=2010-11-11|publisher=El Balon Cuscatleco |language=Spanish |trans_title=Managers}} [[Mauricio Alonso RodrÃ­guez|Pipo RodrÃ­guez]] managed to qualify El Salvador to another [[1982 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]]. Rodiguez participated at the 1970 FIFA World Cup.

Source: ==Records and honours== El Salvador were the first Central American team to qualify for a [[FIFA World Cup]], in 1970, and the first Central American team to qualify twice which they achieved with entry into the 1982 World Cup. They were the first Central American team to ever score a goal in a [[1982 FIFA World Cup|FIFA World Cup]] on June 15, 1982. They were the first Central American country to qualify their football team to the Olympic Games ([[Football at the 1968 Summer Olympics|Mexico 1968]]). They were the first Central American team to sign up for a World Cup qualifier (France 1938). They were the first Central American team to be champions of the [[Football at the Central American and Caribbean Games|Central American and Caribbean Games]] (Mexico 1954). They were also the first Central American team to organize the [[Football at the Central American and Caribbean Games|Central American and Caribbean Games]] (1935) and the first ever [[CONCACAF Championship]] (1963). El Salvador were also the first Central American team to beat {{nft|Mexico}} in Mexico City; by a score of 3-2 at the 1954 Central American and Caribbean Games. Scorers of that game are as follows: Mario Montoya 16' (0-1), Antonio Jasso 27' (1-1), Mario Montoya 36' (1-2), [[Ricardo Valencia]] 37' (1-3), Rafael Gutierrez 64' (2-3). The 1st goal in a World Cup qualifier was scored by Joel Estada on 12 December 1968 against {{nft|Dutch Guiana}}. The 50th goal in a World Cup qualifier was scored by [[Ever HernÃ¡ndez]] in a 1â0 victoryâon 2 December 1981âagainst Mexico. The 100th goal in a World Cup qualifier was scored by Jorge "MÃ¡gico" GonzÃ¡lez on 2 May 1993 against {{nft|Canada}}. The 150th goal in a World Cup qualifier was scored by [[VÃ­ctor VelÃ¡squez]] in a 2â1 victoryâon 13 June 2004âagainst {{nft|Bermuda}}. The 200th goal in a World Cup qualifier was scored by defender [[Xavier GarcÃ­a (footballer)|Xavier GarcÃ­a]] in a 4â1 victoryâon 6 September 2011âagainst the {{nft|Cayman Islands}}.{{cite
